gmx:name.gco:CharacterString: Feature Catalog for Principal Aquifers of the 48 Conterminous United States, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Geological Survey (U.S.). Water Resources Division. Wisconsin District

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: A formation, group of formations, or part of a formation that contains sufficient saturated permeable material to yield significant quantities of water to wells and springs.
The perimeter of the shape in file units. In the distributed file, file units represent decimal degrees.

The names used in this map layer are listed below. There should be a direct correlation between the values of the rock_type and rock_name attributes, and between the aq_name and aq_code attributes. The aq_names are as follows: >aq_code -- aq_name >101 -- Basin and Range basin-fill aquifers >102 -- Rio Grande aquifer system >103 -- California Coastal Basin aquifers >104 -- Pacific Northwest Rocks that are generally poorly permeable but > locally may contain productive aquifers.

The code number relating to the aquifer unit name. There should be a direct correlation between the values of the Rock_type and Rock_name attributes, and between the Aq_name and Aq_code attributes. See table above under Aq_name.
The size of the shape in file units. In the distributed file, file units represent square decimal degrees.
The name of the permeable geologic material that composes the aquifer.
Formations composed of loose sand and gravel.
Formations composed of sandstone, limestone, and (or) dolomite.
Formations composed of limestone and (or) dolomite.
Other rocks. Rocks that are generally poorly permeable but locally may contain productive aquifers.
The representation of the entity in the data.
The code number relating to the rock_name.
